docs.lead_paragraph: The candidates will be dashing around this weekend -- mostly in Iowa and New Hampshire -- in a last-minute push before the short holiday respite they've promised voters (and us). Their schedules have been jammed with events, voters have been waiting and waiting for the candidates to show up as their itineraries and the weather prompt delays.

headline.main: The Early Word: Huckabee Scoffs at 'Christophobia'

docs.abstract: Part of Mike Huckabee's campaign strategy is to cut through political correctness and talk matter of factly about Jesus Christ.
docs.snippet: Part of Mike Huckabee's campaign strategy is to cut through political correctness and talk matter of factly about Jesus Christ.

headline.main: To Our Health, in the New Year
headline.print_headline: To Our Health, in the New Year

docs.lead_paragraph: Republicans have been able to slow and sometimes halt the agenda of Nancy Pelosi and the House Democrats.
docs.snippet: Republicans have been able to slow and sometimes halt the agenda of Nancy Pelosi and the House Democrats.

byline.original: By CARL HULSE  and ROBERT PEAR

docs.lead_paragraph: It all happened so fast that if you blinked you might well have missed the recent brouhaha over the latest public awareness campaign by the Child Study Center, a mental health treatment, advocacy and training institute at New York University. Designed to get across the message that untreated mental disorders hold children "hostage," the ads were made to look like ransom notes that kidnappers had seemingly scribbled on lined paper or clumsily glued together with letters cut out of newspapers.
docs.abstract: An ad campaign about mental disorders hits a nerve.
docs.snippet: An ad campaign about mental disorders hits a nerve.

docs.lead_paragraph: Pundit catfight! Newsweek's Jonathan Alter takes the rare step of calling out a fellow columnist by name --­ in this case, Paul Krugman of The New York Times. "Paul Krugman is a brilliant Princeton economist and fine columnist for The New York Times who was far ahead of the pack in asserting that George W. Bush is a total disaster as president," Alter's column begins. "His clarity in explaining what academics call 'political economy' is without peer. But his attack on Barack Obama on December 17 was wrong on history, wrong on politics and wrong on what the future holds for Obama's 'big table' idea." Alter continues:
docs.abstract: Which Clinton does Obama resemble more?
docs.snippet: Which Clinton does Obama resemble more?

docs.lead_paragraph: FORT DODGE -- Listening to Bill Clinton as he stumps across Iowa on his own, Caucus is struck how different his message is from the "softening" one that has been unfolding at Senator Hillary Clinton's campaign events.

headline.main: Bill's Message This Week: Hillary Gets Results

docs.abstract: Bill Clinton almost exclusively touts his wife's experience, at least for now and at least for Iowa. He stays away from the warm and fuzzy.
docs.snippet: Bill Clinton almost exclusively touts his wife's experience, at least for now and at least for Iowa. He stays away from the warm and fuzzy.

docs.lead_paragraph: Discussing the passage of a $554 billion spending bill by Congress, President Bush told a news conference today that "when Congress wastes so much time and leaves its work to the final days before Christmas, it is not a responsible way to run this government."

docs.lead_paragraph: WOODBRIDGE, N.J. — Moving New Jersey closer to universal health care coverage, Gov. Jon S. Corzine said on Wednesday that the state had reached an agreement with Horizon Blue Cross Blue Shield allowing working- and middle-class families to obtain health insurance for children at drastically reduced rates.
